passages.text: August 28, 2025 06:30 AM GMT
NHK Spring (5991) | Japan
WHAT'S CHANGEDNHK Spring (5991.T)FromPrice Target¥2,100

No change in our expectation for a profit decline this year. HDD suspension profits squeezed by lower prices and higher costs. As profit pressure eases next year we forecast profit growth from higher volumes for near line applications.

- 1Q OP overshot expectations but was in line excluding one-off factors. Full-year OP guidance unchanged at ¥47.0bn. Our forecast unchanged at ¥49.5bn.- Lift F3/27 OP forecast from ¥54.5bn to ¥55.5bn. We had already expected 2-digit growth, but now expect milder rise in fixed costs and decline in prices.- Rising labor costs (higher wages) and lower prices (decline in prototypes) to weigh on F3/26 profit. Such headwinds will likely normalize in F3/27.- In the seat business, we expect Subaru's new Outback model to improve the vehicle mix and enhance seat value, contributing to profit growth in F3/27.- Lacks short-term catalysts but interest likely to shift to F3/27 earnings; stay OW.

Revised forecasts: 1Q OP was strong at ¥11bn, but excluding one- offs (timing differences in seat R&D expenses, unrealized gains from DDS) results broadly matched expectations. DDS volumes rose an estimated \(\sim 30\%\) YoY, but rising fixed costs and price declines weighed on profits. As a result, profit was flat excluding one- offs, and OPM declined to \(20.8\%\) from \(23.6\%\) in 1Q last year. The price drop reflects a rebound from last year's high- priced prototypes, while fixed cost increases stem from domestic wage hikes (both factored into this year's plan). We expect these profit pressures to ease next year, and continued growth in nearline HDD suspension volumes to support a return to profit growth. We also expect contributions from value- added strategies in seats and suspension springs. We keep our F3/26 forecast at ¥49.5bn, but slightly lift F3/27 from ¥54.5bn to ¥55.5bn.

We stay OW and lift our PT from ¥2,100 to ¥2,300: We lift our target P/E for F3/27 from 10.0x to 11.0x. We continue to use a SOTP approach, but raise our P/E for auto parts such as suspension springs and seats to 9.0x, reflecting an industry benchmark increase to 10.0x. We apply a P/E of 12.5x to DDS and SPE components. Although auto parts may face short- term headwinds from weak sales in Japan, the US (Nissan, Subaru), and Thailand, our mid- term outlook for DDS remains positive. Growth drivers include rising suspension volumes for high- capacity HDDs for DCs and rising market share following Suncall's exit from HDD suspensions.
MORGAN STANLEY MUFG SECURITIES CO., LTD.

Expecting order growth in HDD suspensions, SPE parts and metal substrates
Key: - Historical Stock Performance Current Stock Price Price Target
Source: Refinitiv, Morgan Stanley Research

Seats business benefits from recovering orders from Subaru; profitability-oriented stance on seats for Nissan. Growth in components for semiconductor production equipment and HDD suspensions for data centers. Mid- term business expansion of motor cores, one of the core parts of drive motors for HEV/BEV.
Source: Refinitiv, Morgan Stanley Research
Pricing Power: Negative Secular Growth: Positive View descriptions of Risk Rewards Themes here

Stronger-than- expected autos demand pushes F3/27 sales \(5\%\) above the base case. HDD suspension orders grow too, and margins improve. Here, OP reaches about ¥66.5bn. P/E premium over the base case.
F3/25 OP was ¥52.2bn and we forecast ¥49.5bn (Ce: ¥47bn) for F3/26, ¥55.5bn for F3/27, ¥62.5bn for F3/28.

Our target P/E of 11.0x is above our 10.0x industry standard (lower level of the historical range) and is derived using SOTP (9.0x for auto- related including suspension springs and seats, 12.5x for DDS and SPE parts). Reflecting growth potential for semiconductor production equipment, HDD suspensions, metal substrates, and motor cores.
Due to weaker- than- expected autos demand, F3/27 sales fall short of our base case by \(5\%\) . We would expect OP of just ¥45bn in such a scenario. P/E is discounted from the base case.

The medium- term plan announced in May 2024 called for sales of 850bn, OP of 52bn in F3/27. Watch for strengthening of stockholder returns.

Within the last 12 months, Morgan Stanley managed or co- managed a public offering (or 144A offering) of securities of Aisin, Denso, Stanley Electric, Toyoda Gosei, Toyota Industries. Within the last 12 months, Morgan Stanley has received compensation for investment banking services from Aisin, Denso, NHK Spring, Nifco, Stanley Electric, Toyoda Gosei, Toyota Boshoku, Toyota Industries, TS Tech.

In the next 3 months, Morgan Stanley expects to receive or intends to seek compensation for investment banking services from Aisin, Denso, EXEDY, F.C.C., Koito Mfg., Musashi Seimitsu Industry, NHK Spring, Nifco, NK, Stanley Electric, TOKAI RIKA, Toyoda Gosei, Toyota Boshoku, Toyota Industries, TS Tech, Unipres.

Within the last 12 months, Morgan Stanley has either provided or is providing non- investment banking, securities- related services to and/or in the past has entered into an agreement to provide services or has a client relationship with the following company: Aisin, Denso.

Morgan Stanley uses a relative rating system using terms such as Overweight, Equal- weight, Not- Rated or Underweight (see definitions below). Morgan Stanley does not assign ratings of Buy, Hold or Sell to the stocks we cover. Overweight, Equal- weight, Not- Rated and Underweight are not the equivalent of buy, hold and sell. In any case, ratings (or research) should not be used or relied upon as investment advice. (as of July 31, 2025)

The Stock Ratings described below apply to Morgan Stanley's Fundamental Equity Research and do not apply to Debt Research produced by the Firm. For disclosure purposes only (in accordance with FINRA requirements), we include the category headings of Buy, Hold, and Sell alongside our ratings of Overweight, Equal- weight, Not- Rated and Underweight. Morgan Stanley does not assign ratings of Buy, Hold or Sell to the stocks we cover. Overweight, Equal- weight, Not- Rated and Underweight are not the equivalent of buy, hold, and sell but represent recommended relative weightings (see definitions below). To satisfy regulatory requirements, we correspond Overweight, our most positive stock rating, with a buy recommendation; we correspond Equal- weight and Not- Rated to hold and Underweight to sell recommendations, respectively.

Data include common stock and ADRs currently assigned ratings. Investment Banking Clients are companies from whom Morgan Stanley received investment banking compensation in the last 12 months. Due to rounding off of decimals, the percentages provided in the % of total' column may not add up to exactly 100 percent.

Overweight (O). The stock's total return is expected to exceed the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12-18 months.

Equal-weight (E). The stock's total return is expected to be in line with the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12-18 months.

Not-Rated (NR). Currently the analyst does not have adequate conviction about the stock's total return relative to the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12-18 months.

Underweight (U). The stock's total return is expected to be below the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12-18 months.
Unless otherwise specified, the time frame for price targets included in Morgan Stanley Research is 12 to 18 months.
Attractive (A): The analyst expects the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12-18 months to be attractive vs. the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below.

In-Line (I): The analyst expects the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12-18 months to be in line with the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below.Cautious (C): The analyst views the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12-18 months with caution vs. the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below.Benchmarks for each region are as follows: North America - S&P 500; Latin America - relevant MSCI country index or MSCI Latin America Index; Europe - MSCI Europe; Japan - TOPIX; Asia -relevant MSCI country index or MSCI sub-regional index or MSCI AC Asia Pacific ex Japan Index.
